awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Dynamic degradation of proteins by ubiquitination provides a novel  therapeutic for controlling elevated protein levels
awd_abstract_narration:
The ability to tightly control protein level is critical for cell health. High levels contribute to diseases that include cancer, diabetes, dementia, and heart disease. Current treatments do not attempt to degrade excess proteins. We propose to develop a technology that triggers protein degradation and that is reversible. Activities targeted to the general public and to teachers will expand the understanding of the importance of training in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM). Exposing high school and undergraduate students to hands-on laboratory research experiences will help to attract and retain students in STEM fields. Ultimately, this training will result in a globally competitive workforce.


This project will develop a new and potent approach that induces protein degradation by synthetically coupling and directing the native proteasomal degradation machinery towards the desired target protein(s). We will repurpose the Cas6 family proteins as a generalizable platform for site-specific RNA binding and processing, and demonstrate their utility to provide dynamic fine-tuning of protein levels based on intracellular microRNAs (miRNAs) levels. A key challenge in creating a novel technology that can adapt to the changing cellular environment and permit the targeting of essential proteins, which presently is not possible, is to enable dynamic fine-tuning of the protein levels. Towards this end, we will evaluate different strategies to turn off the protein degradation such that the target protein can be maintained at a desirable or set level. We envision that our technology is broadly applicable to any protein and thus will impact many diseases wherein elevated proteins levels contribute to or drive their pathology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated delivery of biomolecules, such as plasmids, nanobodies, nucleic acids, etc. It is underappreciated that the delivery of synthetic materials can impact the function of the cells (e.g., induce endoplasmic reticulum (ER). Similarly, the environment (e.g., fatty acids) can impact their delivery and could explain some of the issues that arose with delivering the Cas6 proteins. ER stress engages the unfolded protein response (UPR), an adaptive reaction that helps to restore cellular homeostasis. The ER plays an important role in cholesterol synthesis. Cholesterol is important not only for constituting the biological membrane but also for regulating a range of cellular processes. Cholesterol is the component of the cell membrane that controls rigidity and permeability – important factors for endocytosis and endosomal escape of RNA-based therapeutics. Increased levels of cholesterol are associated with large, rigid, impermeable endosomes and vesicles, potentially sequestering delivered RNA. The levels of plasma membrane cholesterol are reduced by treating the cells with methyl-ß-cyclodextrin (MßCD). We demonstrated that by removing cholesterol from the cell membrane, silencing is restored. The endomembrane system connects the ER, Golgi, lysosomes, nuclear membrane, and cell membrane through membrane bound vesicle communication. The ER is primarily where lipids are synthesized, thus during ER stress, lipid regulation is altered. Another reason lipid levels tend to increase in ER stressed cells is for autophagy. Proteasomal degradation and autophagy work together to breakdown proteins. Proteasomal degradation is limited to soluble substrates, but autophagy is not. Inhibiting autophagy during transfection in the presence of ER stress decreased the amount of siRNA that accumulates as well as silencing suggesting that autophagy is important for delivery of synthetic biomolecules. Furthermore, we found that upon ER stress, it is possible that the Cas6 proteins, Csy4 and Cse3 were degraded through IRE1-RIDD activity. Finally, we generated and began using human iPSC-derived neuronal cells as a more relevant model than primary rat neural cells due to their translational potential.

 

 


Last Modified: 07/01/2024
Modified by: Christina Chan
